docs.snippet: A Fox function serves up seasonal rewards....
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar weekend, for a blogger who has been mostly typing in his basement, is disconcerting in that suddenly this world he has been flicking at from a distance comes to life before his very eyes.
docs.abstract: A Fox function serves up seasonal rewards.

headline.main: The White Hot Center and the Hole in the Middle of the Donut

docs.snippet: Ellen Page meets the cheez-whiz of the Oscar season with a little gee-whiz....
docs.lead_paragraph: Industry types have taken a few gentle whacks at the diminutive 20-year-old, Ellen Page, suggesting that the star of "Juno" and a best actress nominee has not paid respect to all the glamour and gravitas of the Oscar season as she should. Page is not unaware of the blandishments of the process, she just prefers to treat it as a buffet table, taking some of it and leaving the rest, rather than just diving in. The Bagger interviewed her at the beginning of the season and now at its end, and she has not lost any of her gee-whiz or her innate skepticism of the trappings of stardom.
docs.abstract: Ellen Page meets the cheez-whiz of the Oscar season with a little gee-whiz.

docs.snippet: Glen Hansard on playing the game and playing the big room....
docs.lead_paragraph: Glen Hansard, front man of The Frames and a best song nominee for "Falling Slowly" from "Once," thought for a quick second when the Bagger asked whether he was more intimidated by the prospect of performing for the Oscar hordes or sitting in his seat while the best song winner is announced.
docs.abstract: Glen Hansard on playing the game and playing the big room.

docs.snippet: The peanut gallery now serves mini-burgers. Warming up for the Oscars at the Four Seasons...
docs.lead_paragraph: The bar at the Four Seasons hotel in Beverly Hills is a good place to take a seat in the peanut gallery. In the early evening, Harvey Weinstein motored through, Leslee Dart and Allan Mayer, the reps to the stars, were sharing a drink. Mr. Mayer said that the Oscar weekend's quieter affect had less to do with some mutual agreement to keep a lid on than a kind of opportunity.
docs.abstract: The peanut gallery now serves mini-burgers. Warming up for the Oscars at the Four Seasons

docs.snippet: IN a gift to marketers -- and trivia buffs -- everywhere, The American magazine has put together a fascinating look at ''the diurnal and nocturnal habits'' of the average  resident of the United States.     Here are snapshots from the report compi...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN a gift to marketers -- and trivia buffs -- everywhere, The American magazine has put together a fascinating look at ''the diurnal and nocturnal habits'' of the average resident of the United States. Here are snapshots from the report compiled by Karlyn Bowman, using results from a survey conducted by the Gallup Organization in August.
docs.abstract: What's Offline column; American magazine has put together look at 'diurnal and nocturnal habits' of average resident of US; report was compiled by Karlyn Bowman, using results from survey conducted by Gallup Organization in August; Clayton Neuman in Fast Company magazine offers few tidbits to ponder, should broadcast of Oscars lag on; paper by Cornell University business school, and cited by Atlantic, shows many people believe house listed at precise price of $451,435 is less expensive than one priced at $450,000, even though it is not; magazine says explanation is that because we tend to use precise numbers for small amounts and round numbers for large ones, sellers can make buyers perceive price is smaller than it is by replacing zeros with other digits; of 1,026 men ages 30 to 54 surveyed by Best Life magazine, in conjunction with American Express just 10 percent said they were both 'very happy and very successful'; Reader's Digest, citing research by National Endowment for Arts, says 38 percent of employers consider high school graduates deficient as readers; photo (M)

docs.snippet: The Academy Awards are New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Day rolled into one, a day of reckoning when accounts are tallied, blessings are counted and resolutions are forged anew....

docs.snippet: The odds for the Best Adapted Screenplay Oscar seem to be on the Coen brothers' straight-shooting adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's "No Country For Old Men." But Paul Thomas Anderson could still walk away on Sunday night with the statuette for "Ther...
docs.lead_paragraph: The odds for the Best Adapted Screenplay Oscar seem to be on the Coen brothers' straight-shooting adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's "No Country For Old Men." But Paul Thomas Anderson could still walk away on Sunday night with the statuette for "There Will Be Blood," his freewheeling and darkly poetic reimagining of Upton Sinclair's 1927 novel "Oil!" (Pop quiz: Does anyone know any novelists besides Sinclair and Dave Eggers who have used exclamation points in their titles?)
